text: Mine eyes fail for thy salvation, and for the word of thy righteousness.
text_kjv: Mine eyes fail for thy salvation, and for the word of thy righteousness.
text_niv: My eyes fail, looking for your salvation,looking for your righteous promise.
text_esv: My eyes long for your salvation and for the fulfillment of your righteous promise.
text_nlt: My eyes strain to see your rescue,to see the truth of your promise fulfilled.
text_msg: I can't keep my eyes open any longer, waiting for youto keep your promise to set everything right.
text_nasb: My eyes fail [with longing] for Your salvation And for Your righteous word.
context: Psalm 119 is an acrostic poem, with each section devoted to a letter of the Hebrew alphabet. This psalm, believed to be authored by someone familiar with hardship, is a testament to the beauty and power of God's law. The psalmist, possibly someone in a position of leadership or responsibility, emphasizes the transformative impact of scripture. Understanding the historical context requires recognizing the importance of the Torah (Law) in Jewish life. It wasn't just a legal code but a pathway to a righteous and prosperous life in covenant with God. During periods of exile or oppression, the law became an even more crucial source of hope and identity. The psalmist's 'eyes failing' suggests a prolonged period of waiting, possibly amidst societal turmoil or personal suffering. He is yearning not just for physical deliverance but for the establishment of God's righteous order. The verse speaks to a time of national or personal distress where the promised salvation seems delayed, and the righteous standards of God feel distant. It echoes the plight of the Israelites throughout their history, constantly seeking God's intervention and guidance.
meaning: This verse speaks to the profound human experience of waiting, particularly waiting on God's promises. 'Mine eyes fail' paints a vivid picture of exhaustion and desperation. The psalmist is not merely casually anticipating deliverance; he is actively and intensely longing for it, to the point of physical and emotional depletion. The phrase 'thy salvation' points to God's intervention, not just for personal relief, but for a broader rescue from injustice and suffering. It's a plea for God to act according to His character of justice and mercy. The second part, 'for the word of thy righteousness,' clarifies that the psalmist's desire for salvation is intrinsically linked to a desire for God's righteous standards to be upheld. He is not simply seeking escape from hardship but a restoration of divine order and justice. He trusts God's word as the standard of righteousness and sees salvation as the fulfillment of that word. The righteousness spoken of here refers to God's perfect justice and holiness, demonstrated through his actions and revealed in his law. The psalmist sees the fulfillment of God's word as inseparable from his salvation, demonstrating a deep understanding of the integrated nature of God’s character and promises. He trusts that God will act justly and righteously, thus bringing about the salvation he so desperately craves.
application: In today's world, Psalm 119:123 resonates deeply with those who are facing prolonged trials, injustice, or personal struggles. It reminds us that it's okay to feel weary and discouraged while waiting on God. The psalmist's honesty in expressing his exhaustion provides a powerful example of authentic prayer. When our 'eyes fail' from waiting, we can turn to scripture and find solace in the promises of God. This verse challenges us to examine our own motives for seeking salvation. Are we simply looking for personal comfort, or do we genuinely desire to see God's righteousness established in our lives and in the world around us? This verse compels us to engage with scripture actively. We can emulate the psalmist by grounding our hopes in the 'word of thy righteousness.' Reading and meditating on scripture helps us align our desires with God's will. It also provides clarity and direction during times of uncertainty. Practically, this verse calls us to action. While waiting on God, we can still work towards justice and righteousness in our own spheres of influence. This might involve advocating for the marginalized, speaking out against injustice, or simply living a life that reflects God's values. Sharing our struggles with others and seeking support from a faith community can also help us persevere during times of waiting. The psalmist's plea reminds us to be persistent in prayer and to trust that God hears our cries, even when the answer seems delayed.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I come before you with a heart heavy from waiting. My eyes grow weary, and my spirit feels faint. I long for your salvation, not just for myself, but for a world desperately in need of your justice and peace. Remind me of your promises found in scripture, the 'word of your righteousness' that sustains and guides me. Give me strength to persevere, to continue seeking your face even when I feel discouraged. Help me to align my desires with your will, and to trust that you are working all things together for good. Grant me wisdom to discern your leading and the courage to act according to your word. Thank you for hearing my cry and for your unwavering love. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: The phrase 'eyes failing' powerfully illustrates the intensity and duration of the psalmist's longing. It signifies a state of physical and emotional exhaustion brought on by prolonged waiting and desperate hope for deliverance. It emphasizes the gravity of the situation.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: Why does the psalmist specifically mention 'eyes failing'?

faqs.answer: Psalm 119 extols the virtues and power of God's word. This verse fits into the theme by expressing the psalmist's reliance on God's word as the basis for his hope in salvation. The 'word of thy righteousness' reinforces that reliance.
faqs.question: Q2: How does this verse relate to the rest of Psalm 119?

faqs.answer: The salvation described is multifaceted. It is not only personal deliverance from suffering but also the establishment of God's justice and righteousness in the world. It encompasses both spiritual and earthly realities.
faqs.question: Q3: What kind of 'salvation' is the psalmist referring to?

faqs.answer: While not explicitly mentioned, Christians can see a foreshadowing of Jesus, who embodies God's righteousness and offers salvation to all who believe. Jesus is the ultimate fulfillment of God's promise of salvation.
faqs.question: Q4: Is there any connection to Jesus Christ in this verse?

faqs.answer: The 'word of righteousness' is not just a set of rules, but a reflection of God's character and justice. It's more than legalistic; it’s a guide to living in right relationship with God and others, rooted in love.
